title: Entropy
videoTitle: ME40 - Video 7 - Principle of Maximum Entropy (edited)

subtopics.topic: Entropy Balance Equation for a Closed System
subtopics.summary: Starts by applying the **Entropy Balance** to a closed system: $$\Delta S_{\\text{system}} = \\sum \\frac{Q_k}{T_k} + S_{\\text{gen}}$$. This equation equates the change in system entropy to the sum of entropy transfer (via heat) and entropy generation ($$S_{\\text{gen}}$$) due to irreversibilities.

Discusses the physical meaning of $S_{\\text{gen}}$$. The **entropy generation** term is always $$\ge 0$$. $S_{\\text{gen}} > 0$$ indicates an **irreversible process** (real-world), $S_{\\text{gen}} = 0$$ indicates a **reversible process** (idealized), and $S_{\\text{gen}} < 0$$ indicates an **impossible process**.

subtopics.topic: Entropy Balance for an Isolated System (The Universe)
subtopics.summary: Applies the entropy balance to the **Isolated System** (the system plus surroundings, or 'the universe'). Since $Q=0$$ for an isolated system, $$\Delta S_{\\text{universe}} = S_{\\text{gen}}$$. This leads back to the **Increase of Entropy Principle**: $$\Delta S_{\\text{universe}} \\ge 0$$.

Revisits the T-s (Temperature-Entropy) Diagram, illustrating constant properties (volume, pressure) and the concept of an **isentropic process** ($$\Delta s = 0$$), which appears as a vertical line on the T-s diagram.

Introduces the **Gibbs Equations** (or Tds Relations), which are fundamental relationships between properties: 1) $$T \\text{d}s = \\text{d}u + P \\text{d}v$$ and 2) $$T \\text{d}s = \\text{d}h - v \\text{d}P$$. These are useful for calculating entropy changes for ideal gases.

subtopics.topic: Entropy Change for Ideal Gases (Constant Specific Heats)
subtopics.summary: Derives the entropy change equations for ideal gases assuming constant specific heats ($$c_v, c_p$$): $$\Delta s = c_v \\ln \\left(\\frac{T_2}{T_1}\\right) + R \\ln \\left(\\frac{v_2}{v_1}\\right)$$ and $$\Delta s = c_p \\ln \\left(\\frac{T_2}{T_1}\\right) - R \\ln \\left(\\frac{P_2}{P_1}\\right)$$.

Presents the **Isentropic Relations** for ideal gases with constant specific heats (where $$\Delta s = 0$$): $$\frac{T_2}{T_1} = \\left(\\frac{v_1}{v_2}\\right)^{k-1} = \\left(\\frac{P_2}{P_1}\\right)^{(k-1)/k}$$. Where $k$$ is the specific heat ratio ($$c_p/c_v$$).

subtopics.topic: Connecting Thermodynamics to Basic Rules of the Universe
subtopics.summary: Final summary connecting the **Increase of Entropy Principle** with other fundamental conservation laws (energy, mass, momentum) as the basic rules that govern all processes in the universe, emphasizing its importance in engineering and science.
